raw_text:
Bollywood DVD fraudster is jailed
 
 A major distributor of pirated DVDs of Bollywood films has been sent to prison for three years.
 
 Jayanti Amarishi Buhecha from Cambridge was found guilty of two trademark offences last month, and sentenced at Harrow Crown Court, London, on Tuesday. Buhecha, who made £26,000 per month from his illegal trade, was called "one of the biggest Bollywood pirates in the UK" by the sentencing judge. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) worked for two years on the case.
 
 An operation was launched against Buhecha in 2002 after complaints were received about his activities. The judge in the case, which lasted seven days, said that "a heavy penalty was called for because of the enormous damage Buhecha caused to legitimate business". Fake DVDs were manufactured in Pakistan and Malaysia and sold on wholesale to shops by Buhecha, who traded in conterfeit DVDs in 2002 and 2003.
 
 In December 2002, he was stopped in his car by trading standards officers, who uncovered 1,000 pirated DVDs and faked inlay cards printed with registered trademarks. Despite being arrested and bailed, Buhecha was caught a second time at the end of 2003. His home and a lock-up in Cambridge were found to contain 18,000 counterfeit DVDs and further faked inlay cards. Buhecha was previously a legitimate distributor of Bollywood films, but was suspended and sued by his employers for dealing in illegal copies of Bollywood classic Mohabbatein. Legitimate Bollywood film distributors have hailed the conviction as "a major boost". Bollywood music and film suffers piracy at the rate of 40%, which is more than that suffered by mainstream productions. The BPI welcomed the news of the prison sentence, but warned there are plenty of other active counterfeiters of Bollywood films. The organisation's anti-piracy director David Martin said: "The problem simply will not disappear with Buhecha. Others and more will take his place, so it's vital that keep up our efforts in this field."
llama3.2:1b: A Bollywood DVD distributor was sentenced to three years in prison after being found guilty of trademark offenses related to pirated DVDs. The court ruled he caused £26,000 worth of damage by selling counterfeit copies of films and distributing them across the UK. Buhecha was stopped in 2002 and again in 2003 for allegedly possessing over 18,000 counterfeit DVDs and faked inlay cards from registered trademarks.
llama3.2:3b: Jayanti Amarishi Buhecha, a major distributor of pirated Bollywood DVDs, was jailed for three years after being found guilty of two trademark offenses. He made £26,000 per month from the illegal trade and was called "one of the biggest Bollywood pirates in the UK". The case involved fake DVDs manufactured in Pakistan and Malaysia, sold to shops by Buhecha, and resulted in 18,000 counterfeit DVDs and faked inlay cards being discovered at his homes. Legitimate Bollywood distributors hailed the conviction as a major boost, while the BPI warned that others would take Buhecha's place.
gemma2:2b: Jayanti Amarishi Buhecha, a former legitimate Bollywood film distributor, was sentenced to three years in prison for trademark offences related to selling pirated DVDs of Bollywood films.  He made £26,000 per month from his illegal trade and is considered one of the UK's biggest Bollywood pirates. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) worked on this case for two years.   Buhecha manufactured and sold fake DVDs in both 2002 and 2003.  His home and a lock-up contained 18,000 counterfeit DVDs, and he was caught multiple times for illegal activities.   The case highlights the issue of piracy affecting Bollywood film production and distributors are optimistic about this conviction as a step toward reducing it.

qwen2.5:3b: A major distributor of pirated Bollywood DVDs, Jayanti Amarishi Buhecha from Cambridge, was jailed for three years after being found guilty of two trademark offences by Harrow Crown Court, London. Buhecha made £26,000 per month from illegal trade and manufactured counterfeit DVDs in Pakistan and Malaysia before selling them wholesale to shops in the UK. He was sentenced due to causing significant damage to legitimate business. The case lasted seven days as it revealed he had been caught twice for possessing 18,000 counterfeit DVDs. Buhecha initially traded legit Bollywood films but later dealt in pirated copies. Legitimate distributors welcomed his conviction and BPI, an anti-piracy organisation, praised the news but acknowledged that other counterfeiters might take his place.

smollm:1.7b: Bollywood DVD fraudster is jailed for three years.

A major distributor of pirated DVDs from Bollywood has been jailed for three years. Jayanti Amarishi Buhecha, who made £26,000 monthly, was found guilty of two trademark offences and served a full sentence at Harrow Crown Court in London. He was involved in manufacturing fake DVDs in Pakistan and Malaysia and selling them to him between 2002 and 2003. Despite being arrested, he was caught again in 2003 when stopped in his car, found 1,000 pirated DVDs and faked inlay cards. He was previously a legitimate distributor but now faces legal action from his employers for illegal film sales. The British Phonographic Industry (BPI) acknowledged the guilty verdict but warned of other active counterfeiters and urged ongoing efforts.
